heading: share prices seek a clue
subheading: wall street feels its way along uncertainly as investors weigh a mixed bag of earnings, stock splits, and turbulence abroad. business as usual. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: wall street was still searching for a solid sense of direction in mid-afternoon trading monday, with share prices bouncing back and forth between the plus and minus columns. volatile internet stocks were mixed, but were generally holding firm as investors struggled to come up with a good reason to resume their love affair with all things .com. the dow jones industrial average rose 6.18 points to 9126.85. the nasdaq composite index gained 11.85 to 2350.73, and the s&p 500 was down 0.23 at 1224.96.while the current earnings season has yet to produce any serious bumps and bruises, traders are finding their anxiety level heightened by the sight of slow-to-act brazil forming bucket brigades to put out its economic brush fire. at the same time, speculation continues that china is on the verge of devaluing its currency, which would have a potentially severe impact on efforts to stabilize asia's finances."the assumption is that the brazilian problem will spill over to other latin american countries," said alexander paris sr., an analyst with barrington research. "that would hurt exports of us companies."as for china, he observed that "asia has generally been in a recovery mode." a devaluation of the yuan "would really sink the region again."still, such a prospect has had a relatively limited impact on us stocks. investors seem to have learned from last year's unwarranted fears of looming global recession that even the scariest collapse abroad doesn't necessarily mean wall street's demise is imminent.this small comfort is allowing traders to instead focus on the here and now -- such as at&t (t) sliding us$2 to $86.25 even as it reports a 58-percent hike in quarterly profit to $1.12 a diluted share, in line with expectations. however, revenues were up just 4.8 percent, prompting many investors to wonder if the telco's stock isn't a tad pricey for such modest growth.meanwhile, citigroup (c) advanced $1.56 to $53.19 after posting fourth-quarter income of 60 cents a share, excluding one-time charges. this was 4 cents ahead of earlier estimates.microsoft (msft) muscled its way $5.38 higher to $161.63 as it announced a two-for-one stock split for shareholders of record as of 12 march. by the end of last month, the software giant had approximately 2.5 billion common shares outstanding. the split will double that number.online broker ameritrade (amtd) was also doing some stock splitting, revealing its own two-for-one divvy following a big run-up in the company's share price. ameritrade, which last week reported better-than-expected earnings of 13 cents a share, gained $3.88 to $53.88.america online (aol) rose $1.94 to $142.38 following a report in the wall street journal europe that netscape communications co-founder marc andreessen will become chief technology officer at the world's biggest online service after the merger of the two companies is completed. such a development would help to allay fears among some netscape stalwarts that the company had sold its soul for a $4.2 billion payday.online auctioneer ebay (ebay) climbed $16.38 to $213.13 after cutting a marketing accord with compaq computer. this helped to distract attention from a story in the new york post that the company is being investigated for alleged consumer fraud by new york city officials. it's possible that certain one-of-a-kind sports memorabilia were sold to more than one buyer, the post said.oops.rival auction house ubid (ubid) rose 25 cents to $71.13 after the company posted a narrower-than-anticipated quarterly loss of 24 cents a share. analysts had been fearing a setback of at least 26 cents. an outfit called 2themart.com (tmrt), meanwhile, advanced 25 cents to $16 on word that it has secured funding for a little auction action of its own.let's just come right out and say it now: this nuttiness over online auctions is going to blow by faster than you can say "push technology."be warned.
